body: There were days upon days in New York City when not a single person was murdered in 2009. Two such stretches, in February and March, lasted nearly a week each. There were some pockets of the city where homicide was a singular occurrence: 12 of the city's 77 police precincts, in locations as varied as Hamilton Heights, in Upper Manhattan, and Park
title: HOMICIDES NEAR RECORD LOW RATE IN NEW YORK CITY

body: Bumper Cars Cobble Hill is a neighborhood of old brownstones and narrow streets. body: Of all the tiny tortures that come with driving a car in New York City, perhaps none are more taxing than the ritual of alternate-side-of-the-street parking. title: A Bronx Parking Paradise, for a While

title: Off The Menu

body: TEN years is a respectable run for a New York restaurant. Most don't make it that long, and many of those that do are slowly taking on water. A few may change course by bringing a new chef on board or, more and more frequently these days, trimming their sails and tacking toward cheaper, more casual shores. Saul is a heartening exception. One of the
title: RESTAURANTS; Still Neighborly in Brooklyn

body: AFTER 37 years in their house on Dean Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, Norman and Roselyn Kopit decided last summer that it was finally time for a change of scene. title: LIVING IN | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; Subway Lines Galore, but Who's Leaving?

author: Lucinda Rosenfeld is the author of ''I'm So Happy for You: A Novel About Best Friends.''
body: A THERAPIST once observed that I care a lot about how things look. I remember feeling hurt. She was right, of course. I used to obsess about my skin, my weight, my clothes, even my cuticles. These days, all I seem to care about is the appearance of my home, a circa 1852 brownstone in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, that looks, to my perfectionist eye, like
title: DOMESTIC LIVES; The Honey-Don't List

body: SEVERAL years ago, the stretch of Atlantic Avenue that runs from Flatbush Avenue to the East River used to be identifiable primarily for having an antique row on one end and Brooklyn's main Arab community on the other. body: By the time lunch was over, flour coated all the workstations at the culinary school in Brooklyn. Shards of dough stuck to the surfaces. title: Where Little Chefs Learn the Art of Slicing and Dicing

body: Retro Pricing To celebrate its 20th anniversary Sac's Place, an Italian restaurant and pizzeria at 25-41 Broadway, Astoria, Queens, will roll prices back on the in-house dinner menu to what they were in 1989, for reductions of 30 to 40 percent. author: Lucinda Rosenfeld is a Brooklyn novelist whose latest book, ''I'm So Happy for You: A Novel About Best Friends,'' is out this week. She has seven Twitter followers, but has yet to tweet. Join a reader discussion and read previous complaints at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: A FEW weeks ago, my publisher's online marketing director suggested I join Twitter as a way of ''building my community.'' ''But what do I tweet?'' I asked her. Imagine you're at a cocktail party, she said. The things you'd say to people you met there -- those are the kinds of things you should tweet. Also, people like links. I registered. I signed
title: COMPLAINT BOX | TWEET NOTHINGS; I Can See You Just Fine From Here

body: THE TREASURE HUNTER Jack Fortmeyer, 69, a retired firefighter, began collecting old bottles in the 1960s when he bought a box full at an upstate yard sale for $5. title: One in 8 Million

title: As Cultures Clash, Brooklyn Principal Faces Assault Charges

body: PAULA HAYES likes collisions, particularly those involving meteors, because they give birth to crystals, structures she's enthusiastic about right now. ''Meteors! Dynamism! title: AT HOME WITH PAULA HAYES; Love Alters the Landscape

body: THE old-fashioned may finally be earning its name. One of the most venerable of whiskey-based cocktails, it has a history that stretches back farther than the martini's. title: Take a Sip Of History

body: Two more New Yorkers have died with confirmed cases of swine flu, the city's health commissioner said on Tuesday, bringing the city's total number of deaths related to the virus to four. title: Two More New Yorkers With Swine Flu Die, and Hospital Visits Soar

title: FOOD STUFF; Sweet Somethings From Brooklyn

title: Manhattan Calling

title: Made in Brooklyn

body: Moe Issa, a developer and a Brooklyn native, found what he wanted: a 6,000-square-foot space in Boerum Hill where residential towers are sprouting. title: FOOD STUFF; Whetting Boerum Hill's Appetite

body: So woefully forgotten are L. J. Davis's novels of Brooklyn that not even he has copies on hand in his apartment. title: For a Brooklyn Tale, and Its Author, a Second Chance at a First Impression

body: SPOKES: THEFTS May Be Down Bike theft and its cousin, bike abandonment, are aspects of urban cycling as sure as broken glass, potholes and the lurking threat of being doored. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: YASMINA REZA lives in Paris and writes her award-winning plays in French, so it comes as a quick twist when the characters in the new Broadway production of ''God of Carnage'' start out by discussing the relative safety of two small parks in South Brooklyn. title: URBAN STUDIES; Two Brooklyn Parks, Entering Stage Left

body: A Brooklyn judge has cleared the way for the city to resume sending inmates to the Brooklyn House of Detention, which stopped housing them overnight in 2003, but has ruled that the city's effort to nearly double the size of the jail required environmental and land-use reviews. title: Court Allows Brooklyn Jail To Reopen

body: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, Stephanie Stern and her husband poured 1,000 wriggling red worms from a brown bag into a plastic bin outside their bathroom, looked down and hoped for the best. title: Urban Composting: A New Can of Worms

body: FOR more than three months, Tanya Tribble lived in what she called ''the bubble.'' title: THE SELL; A Deal Squared by a Round Number

body: ''I'M really a modernist,'' said Serine Hastings, who lived in prewar apartments her first three decades in New York. Since moving from Chicago in the late 1970s, she has always made her home in places with vintage architectural details. title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; After All Those Brownstones, a Blank Canvas

title: BOERUM HILL JOURNAL; A Block That Wanted Development Has to Wait

body: Jolene Siana, a writer in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, plans to spend time with friends at their homes rather than in wine bars, bringing a $12 bottle rather than blowing $12 on a glass.
